1 killed (DK)http://icasualties.org/Iraq/Fatalities.aspx |casualties2= unknown }} {{Campaignbox Iraq War}} The '''Siege of UK bases in Basra''' was conducted and maintained by the [[Mahdi Army]] in [[Basra]] for most of 2007. Following the reported success of the coalition [[Operation Sinbad]], whose purpose was to stabilise Basra and prepare it for the turning over of security to Iraqi government forces, the city was overrun by insurgent forces from three different militia forces, including the Mahdi Army, and the British found themselves under siege in their bases and capable of conducting only limited raids in armoured convoys into the city. ==The Bases== By this point in the war there were only two British bases left in Basra. One was on the outskirts of the city at the [[Basra International Airport|Basra Airport]] with a garrison of 5,000 soldiers. The second, which took most of the brunt of the fighting, was in the city center at [[Basra Palace]], a former palace of [[Saddam Hussein]], with a garrison of 700 soldiers.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/iraq/article2242151.ece Under siege - Times Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110145456/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/iraq/article2242151.ece |date=January 10, 2008 }} ==The Siege== [[File:Basra-Shatt-Al-Arab.jpg|thumb|Basra city.]] The first British soldier that was killed in the city, following operation Sinbad, was killed on 27 February returning to the Shatt-Al-Arab Hotel.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6406271.stm "MoD names soldier killed in Iraq"] BBC News 28 February 2007 The airport base was being constantly hit by mortar and rocket fire during the siege but the Basra City battlegroup at the palace was involved in most of the fighting. The Uti Triangle, a flat zone combining open wasteland, marsh and clustered buildings, was being used by the Mahdi army to conduct the [[Mortar (weapon)|mortar]] and [[Rocket-propelled grenade|rocket]] attacks on both the airport and the palace.{{citation |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/iraq/article2224987.ece |title=Death in Basra: the British under siege |publisher=Times Online |date=August 9, 2007 |work=the Times |archivedate=16 August 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816092226/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/iraq/article2224987.ece }} More than 300 rockets hit the airport in the two months between June and August. Sniper attacks were also a deadly and common occurrence for British soldiers as well as [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] attacks on patrols that were going out of the bases. The IED attacks and organised ambushes also hit convoys from the airport that were transporting needed food, fuel, ammunition and other equipment for the palace. Convoys were primarily used for this task because helicopters couldn't be used because of the high risk of being shot down. ==Retreat from Basra Palace== On September 3, under the cover of darkness and without any [[News media|media]] attention, the British withdrew their troops from Basra Palace to the airport, leaving their last foothold they had in the city. Basra was left to the militias.[http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/middle_east/july-dec07/basra_09-03.html British withdraw from Basra - PBS Newshour] ==Aftermath== Following the withdrawal the UK was heavily criticized for pulling back from the city, mostly by the U.S. military.{{ citation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/09_september/29/iraq.shtml |title=Senior US military say British suffered "defeat" in Basra and left people of the city to be "terrorised" |date=29 September 2010 |publisher=BBC Press Office}} Formally, control of the city had been handed over to Iraqi security forces, but in effect the control of the city was in the hands of radical militias{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}. They led a [[wikt:turf war|turf war]] in the coming months over control of the city and up to 100 people, mostly civilians, were being reported killed each month. A [[black market]] monopoly formed over the oil exports from the city. At the end of March 2008, the situation in the city led to an Iraqi troop surge into the city and the 2008 [[Battle of Basra (2008)|Battle of Basra]]. British troops remained in control of Basra Airport until 2009 when it was handed over to Iraqi civilian control. ==See also== {{Portal|Iraq}} * [[Battle of Amarah]] * [[Battle of Diwaniya]] * [[Iraq War]] * [[Iraqi insurgency (Iraq War)|Iraqi insurgency]] * [[List of United Kingdom Military installations used during Operation Telic]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{2007 Operations}} {{Iraq War}} {{coord missing|Iraq}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Basra}} [[Category:Military operations of the Iraq War]] [[Category:Military operations of the Iraq War involving the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Military operations of the Iraq War involving Denmark]] [[Category:Iraqi insurgency (2003–11)]] [[Category:2006 in Iraq]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2006]] [[Category:2007 in Iraq]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2007]] [[Category:History of Basra]]
